description: The modern form was probably borrowed into English and other European languages from Dutch gekko (1718). Contemporary English forms were chacco (1711) and jackoa (1724). The further origin is not quite clear. Some sources mention a supposed Malay gekok, gekoq, or gekop, which would be imitative of the gecko’s chirping sound. Another theory derives it from Acehnese gèh-gòh (“busy”).

entries.meaning: Any lizard of the family Gekkonidae. They are small, carnivorous, mostly nocturnal animals with large eyes and adhesive toes enabling them to climb on vertical and upside-down surfaces.

verbs.description: gecko (third-person singular simple present geckos, present participle geckoing, simple past and past participle geckoed)

entries.meaning: (rare) To move in the manner of a gecko; to attach to a vertical or upside-down surface.
